meta_data.title: Those Are Great Ideas, But How Are You Going to Pay For That?
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 10:37-39 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. It's fast, fun, free, daily deep-dye Bible. And right now we're working on the book of Me Amaya. If you're new, welcome. You can jump in right here, or you can always go back and start at the beginning of any season. The whole podcast is available in an easy to use format at theEMbh.com. Long, long ago in my country, but recent enough for me to remember, there were debates, presidential debates. And the way these would work is you would have the two candidates that were running from our two major political parties. We call them the Democrats and the Republicans, and they each would have somebody who they nominated. Then the two candidates would get up there, and for sometimes two hours, they would talk about, get this, ideas. They would discuss the country and how it was going, and they would discuss different problems and different proposed solutions to those problems. Sometimes they would have a little bit of a laugh with each other, shake hands before and after the debate. And as a citizen, as a voter, you would come away feeling like, okay, well, there's a lot of pressure there, and that wasn't perfect, but it was nice to hear two people making their different cases for why their proposed ideas might work better with some specifics mixed in there so that I could evaluate that for myself. That is not how debates work now. We don't, like ideas aren't really the focus of those. I don't really understand what debates are now, but back in the day, this was the point. And one of the questions that would always get asked in those debates was, how are you gonna pay for it? This is an age-old question. How are you gonna pay for it? How are you gonna pay for it? Well, look, for the last few days, we have been looking at the part of Nehemiah chapter 10, and specifically the part of the covenant ratified by the descendants of Abraham and 444 BC in Jerusalem, under the leadership of Ezra and Nehemiah, we've been looking at the part of the covenant where they answer the question, okay, how are we gonna pay for it? Because they have these lofty ideals, right? The leaders have said, oh, we gotta have this temple. God wants us to have this temple, and God himself has said, I want you to have this temple, and we gotta sacrifices and all these priestly, even pastoral roles and services that are provided here. This is very important. This is a centerpiece of our society. But it's such a big deal and so expensive to run and to maintain that we gotta have a strategy for how we're going to pay for this lofty thing that looks like it's sort of our top priority. And we've looked at a lot of the different ways that funding that was to be accounted for. Everybody's gonna pay a temple tax. It's gonna be a third of a shekel each year. We learned that that's even a slight reduction from the original temple tax that have been instituted 800 or 1,000 years earlier that was half a shekel each year. So presumably behind that, there's some sort of negotiation that occurred to make this sustainable and something that would work for people where everybody could buy in, but it would destroy people's households or anything like that. And then we've also got provisions for providing wood and livestock and crops and first fruit and wine and stuff like that. So all right, the bases are covered. And then yesterday in that mega monster gigantic episode, we talked about another, how are you gonna pay for it thing? Well, in this case, how are you gonna staff it was the question and well, there's a provision for that as well. So there's a lot of how are you gonna pay for that Senator kind of stuff being handled here and now as we get toward the end of Nehemiah chapter 10, we get to the end of the part about how are you gonna pay for it? How are we gonna fund these lofty ideals? And this is what we get in the home stretch, Nehemiah 10, 37. Moreover, this is the descendants of Abraham speaking here together in unison. Moreover, we will bring to the store rooms of the house of our God, to the priests, the first of our ground meal of our grain offerings, of the first fruit, of all of our trees, of our new wine and oil, and we will bring a tie of our crops to the Levites for it is the Levites who collect the tithes in all the towns where we work. And there's a little more here, we'll get to that in just a minute. Okay, so there was a store room, there was a treasury for the temple that existed with the first temple, that's the one that was built by Solomon, 500 years in change before the stuff we're reading about here in Nehemiah chapter 10, around 1000-ish BC. That of course, as we've discussed a lot, got destroyed just brick by brick, totaled, wrecked. In 586 BC by Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. And now this new temple has been rebuilt, we read about that in Ezra. It's been up and running for 70 years or so at this point. And there's a new store room, a new treasury in there. The old one got totally depleted, emptied out. Nebuchadnezzar took everything away. There was a king who stupidly opened up his safe and showed some Babylonian emissaries. Like, oh, here's our first temple, and here's our royal treasury and our store rooms and everything. And that wasn't a good idea. And Babylon was like, oh, there's a lot of free money. He's just sitting there, we should go take it. And it's part of what led to the conquest and collapse of Jerusalem in the Southern Kingdom of Judah, but all of that stuff. I mean, the gold and the silver and all of the furnishings and everything from the temple, that stuff gets profaned and bastardized by some of the later kings of Babylon. In fact, that's what's happening in the scene in the book of Daniel when Cyrus and the Persians show up and bring God's judgment and reckoning against the Babylonians for all of that. But still you've had this huge depletion and plundering that's occurred from these old store rooms from the old temple. Some of it's come back at the order of the achaemenid kings. They've said, all right, take this stuff back. These are the treasures of your people. But also you gotta think about store rooms, the thing about treasures like this, you gotta keep filling this back up. I mean, they're expenses. Things are constantly getting drained off. So what we're reading about here is how that's gonna happen. Now, some of this is perishable stuff. You can't keep wine or grain or whatever in your store rooms for all of eternity. You have to use it in a certain amount of time. But then some of the financial contributions, it would actually literally be in gold or silver, whatever. I mean, it's the kind of stuff that you can keep around for much longer or precious items, stones, things like that. And so the tithe being talked about here, representative 10% of what people were earning is kind of gonna be measured out in two different ways. The most practical way is what normal people would have. Not everybody was dragging around a whole lot of coin. For the most part, the tithe wouldn't have been collected that way. In a sense, it really was kind of a tax collecting role that looks like carried out by these Levites, the people who help make the whole temple thing happen, where it looks like some kind of evaluation occurred. This feels weird and culty if it's happening now to do it this way. But back in the day, I mean, look, this is a voluntary covenant. They're all agreeing to this because they want to. This isn't enforced by the state. This is a very unique people with a very unique relationship with God. And the Levites are the people who go around are like, hey, it looks like about this much is what should be brought to the temple store rooms. This is the tithe this year. Presumably, most of that is gonna be in the form of perishable and probably some of that was gonna be in the form of actual wealth as well. The idea of the tithe hearkens back to a few different places in the first five books of the Bible, a really notable one is in Deuteronomy 14, starting in verse 22. So again, this is 800 or 1000 years before the stuff we're reading about in Nehemiah. It says, be sure to set aside a tenth of all that your fields produce each year. Eat the tithe of your grain, new wine and oil and the first born of your herds and flocks and the presence of the Lord, your God. At the place he will choose is a dwelling for his name so that you may learn to revere the Lord, your God always. But at that place is too distant. And so it goes on to kind of describe how the tithe was to be used in the transitional period here before they went and conquered the Canaan setup shop there and the passage wraps up with, and do not neglect the Levites living in your towns for they have no allotment or inheritance of their own. So the tithe is being used to prop up this one people group of this unique role of service. People are kind of consecrated to the religious life of the people. And that is referenced back to in Numbers chapter 18 where there's this whole lengthy passage about the idea of a national tithe being used to fund the Levites and specifically the idea of this tithe, this 10% gift to the Lord that is to be used by the Levites is there because the Levites don't have an inheritance. The people who are operating in this priestly and supporting priestly capacity, they don't own lands or titles. And so they have to depend on this tithe to function to be functioning families in society numbers 18, 21. I give to the Levites all the tithes in Israel as their inheritance in return for the work they do while serving at the tent of meeting. They don't have a temple yet back here in Numbers is still a mobile temple, if you will, a proto temple, a tabernacle, a tent of meeting. For now on the Israelites must not go near the tent of meeting or they will bear the consequence of their sin and will die. So the Levites, the priestly people, they have a unique role. They are kind of mediators in this sense. So it's a very important role. It is the Levites who are to do the work at the tent of meeting and bear the responsibilities for the offenses against it. This is a lasting ordinance for the generations to come. They will receive no inheritance among the Israelites. Instead, I give to the Levites as their inheritance. The tithes that the Israelites present is an offering to the Lord. So all of this language is gonna feel very distant and very ancient and very foreign to us. But the idea of a tithe certainly carries forward into the New Testament and into the age of the church. I mean, there've been a few expressions of the Christian church that have been funded by formal governmental taxation. But generally that's turned pretty weird, pretty quick when you mingle the church and the state in that way, issues of conscience start to come into play. It sort of lights a fuse on a long-term social and religious time bomb when you do that. The better model seems to have always been this voluntary thing like what we're seeing here in Nehemiah 10 where people come together and they say, this is really important and we're gonna fund it. And the tithe has been a system, both in the Old Testament and the New Testament and the age of the church. And even now it's been a system to account for having a volunteer-based plan to fund this very important thing, this very important role in society. And so the passage rounds out saying a priest descended from Aaron is to accompany the Levites when they receive the tithes, the ancient line of the descendants of Aaron. These are where the priests come from. And the Levites are to bring a tenth of the tithes up to the house of God, to the store rooms of the treasury, back to that concept, we're still replenishing that from the plundering that happened under Nebuchadnezzar in 586 BC. The people of Israel, including the Levites, started to bring their contributions of grain, new wine and oil to the store rooms where the articles for the sanctuary are kept and where the ministering priests, the gatekeepers and the singers stay, quote, we will not neglect the house of our God. And that phrase is both a summary of the vast majority of this covenant pledge that they all just made, but it's also a statement of priority. That's kind of a summary of everything about Ezra and Nehemiah and that demonstrates the newfound commitment and the new focus that the descendants of Abraham are gonna have coming out of the end of the Old Testament. And we gotta talk about that a whole bunch more later on. All right, that's technically the end of Nehemiah, chapter 10 and this whole covenant thing that we're gonna talk about. Tiny bit more next time around. So I'll be looking forward to that. But first, a couple of quick things. One, Patreon, which is a place where many of you support the program, I'm so grateful for that, that they have a clumsy system where from time to time they sort of do a purge of patrons because much like in my family from time to time, my credit cards expire and if they remain expired for a couple of months, Patreon, I don't know if they even tell you, they just take you off the thing. And so on the one hand, that can be a great way to take an off ramp from supporting the program. That's totally cool. This never was for everything. Grateful for you being able to kick in for the time that you were. On the other hand, if you were wanting to continue to support this and be a part of it, that might be worth going and checking because Patreon just purged a whole bunch of you here in some sort of middle of the night expired credit card thing that they just did. Whatever's cool, either way, I'm so grateful. Also though, Jeff Foote, who does all the music on this program just took that Nehemiah names episode thing that we did a couple of weeks ago and distilled it down to just the music and then put a whole bunch of other instruments on it. And it's funny and delightful. And if you haven't been over to Patreon for a while, you should go check that out because I uploaded that quote unquote song for your enjoyment over there. And we'll send that out as an email to everybody who's supporting on other platforms as well, real quick here also. Whether you support the program or not, I'm so grateful to all of you for being here. Thanks for hanging out with me. I'm Matt, this is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon. So. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.
